text: do you miss me edy Koch was New York
City's mayor for 12 years he was once
called the quintessential New Yorker and
I'm just this little Jewish kid from the
Bronx brash tough funny and depending on
who you were your best friend or your
worst enemy I said listen to me that's
the last time I will tell you if you
ever lied to me again you're fired
during his tenure he brought a frazzled
city back from the brink of bankruptcy
they gave people back their spirit Koch
was defeated in 1989 but he never left
the limelight born in 1924 Ed Koch grew
up in Brooklyn the Bronx and Newark New
Jersey he served as an infantryman in
World War two then earned a law degree
from New York University he began
practicing law in 1949
now when you became a lawyer after the
war how did you envision your life did
you see a career in politics ahead of
you no what were you gonna be I was
gonna be a real lawyer a real lawyer I
am moved in 1956 to the village and I
didn't know anybody so I went to the
local Reform club volunteered I became
the street speaker and I really learned
to speak in the streets carried around a
chair I my law office was on wall street
and door at noon I would go downstairs
and speak in the subtreasury steps and
at that particular corner every day no
more but every day when I was there they
would have preachers talking about death
and Jesus and the world to come and
holy rollers they called them at the
time it was one across the street while
I'm talking about the the atom bomb the
hydrogen bomb he's talking about the
life to come
but an Irish cop comes along and he says
Reza permit and I said obviously you
don't need a permit if you're not using
a sound device yeah don't tell me that
where's your permit I said I don't have
a program can you get out of here yeah
I'll take you in
I said officer there is a guy across the
street he's there every day yelling
screaming you never bothered him
Hillary asked him for a permit he said
he's different he's a fanatic God helped
me that's a true story word-for-word so
I got off the chair down 63 you became a
recognized figure leader that's because
I beat carmine DeSapio
you had to do something to become a
leader his victory over DeSapio a
longtime boss of the Democratic machine
called Tammany Hall launched conscious
political career he became the district
representative of Greenwich Village then
he moved up to the City Council now when
you want a seat on the City Council yeah
in 66 you ran on the major liberal
issues of the day for everything from
anti-poverty programs to rent control
now mayor were you a 60s liberal or were
you something else
I've always been amazing I've never been
a radical and that's always surprised
people because coming from Greenwich
Village everybody would think oh he must
be a radical yeah the truth is I've
always been a mainstreamed scoop Jackson
kind of a Democrat and that really came
out when on one occasion
I was running the Women's League
interviewed everybody and then at the
very end very distinguished-looking
elderly woman at the time said I know I
know the answer to this but I have to
ask it for the record
you're of course against the death
penalty no I'm for the death penalty
oh she screamed honest to god
she screamed so that distinguished me
from a lot of liberals and reformers
because that issue was considered to be
a right-wing issue I did not
I always said it's a liberal issue if
you want to protect society now you were
elected to Congress in 68 from the 17th
district the silk nobody trying to could
win you're the first Democrat to
represent it since 1934 how'd you do it
well I was running against Whitney North
senior junior and he thought he was
starting his career in a major way he
was already a state senator his father
was the head of the American Bar
Association and I'm just this little
Jewish kid as I saw myself and all we
see myself even at age 82 from the Bronx
Koch waged a shoe-leather campaign
walking the district every day handing
out literature pressing the flesh it
paid off he won by 2500 votes
in 1969 Koch joined a democratically
controlled Congress by 1972 it's war
with the White House deepened as the
Watergate scandal unraveled Richard
Nixon's presidency well I was an arch
liberal at the time I belong to every
single group that was anti Nixon in the
Congress that you know that there are
dozens of groups that you can belong to
the Wednesday Club the Tuesday Club the
Monday breakfast I mean I can't don't
remember the names but I belong to them
and they were all devoted to how do we
bring this guy down how do we impeach
him and it was fun while Watergate
festered New York was going broke
Koch learned of the financial crisis
from a banker who came to Congress with
the bad news and it's like talking with
a guy who has just escaped from a
concentration camp you don't know what's
happening up there the banks are not
gonna lend any money this is next we're
gonna go into bankruptcy and on and I
mean nobody had had it the slightest
tremor that this was happening in New
York not the slightest in 1977 with the
city still in deep financial crisis Koch
entered the race for mayor he beat out
six others in the first runoffs then he
squared off with Mario Cuomo the runoff
with Mario Cuomo yeah got ugly oh it did
he was very ugly and some of the
supporters started going around saying
vote for Cuomo not the homo they put up
the signs on Queens Boulevard
it was the whole boulevard it was
shocking how do you deal with something
like that well I'll tell you how I know
whether any shocking
I called Mario a weekend or two before
the election and I said Mario this is
happening oh I really I mean he I mean
he doesn't know about it I said marry oh
you got to do something about that it's
not right I'll try I'll do I don't
believe he did anything now that matter
has affected our relationship from 77
through this year we get along and we
got along as mayor and governor but I
always held it against him
I also held it against his son Andy
Cuomo
even though social relationships when we
meet in public are good underneath he
knows I know what I'm really thinking
you and you dealt with this particular
issue the vote for Cuomo the whole thing
by saying it I think this was if not
unique unusual for a politician saying
it's none of anybody's damn business let
me talk to you about this yeah my
reaction was to say it's none of your
business and people who voted for me
some of them thought and think I'm gay
some of them think I'm not and most of
them don't care
Koch won the Democratic primary with his
tough love approach to the city's
problems in the tumultuous summer of
1977 it was the Summer of Son of Sam it
was the summer of the blackout and the
riots primarily in Brooklyn people were
upset I would say that a good part of my
victory was attributable to my reaction
to the riots I said if we don't have
enough cops then bring in the National
Guard
you can't riot with impunity in this
town and regrettably you can
because we don't have a response and we
let some riots people who are stealing I
mean what are they stealing shoes liquor
ruining their own neighborhoods and
people like that there was a real
feeling that summer I remember it
vividly you know that the fabric of the
city was coming apart correct and it was
I wanted people to know that they could
count on me I'm a middle-class guy I
have your values I'm not one of these
jerks who's running around trying to
change the world by rioting or whatever
else the most arch radical wants to do I
want to get things done and we'll make
it better not perfect
in November 1977 Ed Koch was elected the
mayor of New York he inherited a deeply
troubled city when you took office the
city was falling apart fiscally and
physically right what did you intend
spiritually in the sense of the way
people felt about themselves yeah yeah
so what do you tackle I will tell you
I'm not a financial genius not at all
but I know you don't spend money that
you don't have I'm filled in on the
array and the city's problems in the
financial situation I'm told by the
budget people we have no money therefore
and you know I believe my people so when
the labor people came in and they wanted
to negotiate and they want to raise I
said don't be foolish there's no money
here no money there's no food in the
cabinet then there's nothing in the
refrigerator there's not gonna be any
increase words to that effect and just
like that what's the labor people know
more about your budget and how much is
there than you do and they said mayor
you're wrong you got money you got money
and we want it so I go to the budget
people and I say listen did you tell me
the truth when you said there was no
money and they're looking very sheepish
and I know that they didn't tell me the
truth I said listen to me that's the
last time I will tell you if you ever
lied to me again
you're fired and I want you to know you
think that I'll give away things that
you wouldn't give away I don't give away
I'm here to protect the city but I gotta
know what the truth is what
facts are if I'm gonna do it you
understand mayor Koch and the state
financial control board put the city on
a painful fiscal diet within five years
its economic health began improving
during your 12 years as mayor what
people or political forces did you come
to regard as implacable enemies the
unions and some of the banks I mean the
people they used to run the city the
unions and the banks around the city to
some extent they still have more power
than they should you were re-elected in
1981 with 75 percent of the vote so what
in the world possessed you to run for
governor
that's easy hubris I loved the job
people loved me we were a great match I
had sworn on one occasion I had said at
the Western Wall that I would never run
for anything else because I wanted to be
mayor for life now I had forgotten and
interview that I had given oh six months
earlier and in the interview at the end
yes a question which is well what do you
make of all these people are leaving the
city and going upstate I'm paraphrasing
don't be ridiculous you mean upstate
where the men wear polyester suits and
the women gingham dresses and they all
run around and pickup trucks
don't be ridiculous the interview
published in Playboy magazine alienated
upstate voters but it wasn't just slips
of the tongue that hurt Koch during his
third term two scandals neither directly
connected to Koch tarnished his
administration in 1986 donald Maness the
Queens borough president fell under
investigation for taking kickbacks man
has committed suicide a few months after
the report surfaced in the Bronx stanley
friedman another democratic power broker
was proved corrupt and landed in prison
the only really
low spot yeah for you as mayor was when
a series of really unconnected graft and
patronage scandals came bubbling up out
of the Brooklyn and Queens and brought
us political machines and you said you
even consider killing yourself I went
into a state of depression I have to
keep your sense of yourself if you're
made you can't go to a doctor and be
treated for depression public thinks
that has a crazy man at that at the helm
can't do it at least I couldn't do it so
I didn't tell anybody
suffered you know what depression means
it's physical one Sunday I'm lying in
bed I can't get out of bed the telephone
calls from the Cardinal John Cardinal
O'Connor and he says said I know you're
depressed and you shouldn't be everybody
knows you're an honest man
everybody I can heal Seth
so I said your eminence I can't thank
you enough for this call you don't know
what it means
he said not at all it not at all
I said your evidence syllabub what you
Rebbe didn't call me to tell me this is
you did you have a plan for life after
politics or were you gonna run forever
talking about forever remember of what
time I gotta be
Ed Koch never retired when we spoke in
2007 he was putting the finishing
touches on two new books hosting a
weekly radio show in New York City can
you hear me out
what's up and writing movie reviews what
do you feel are the legacies that you
have left this city well most people
would concede the following I
reestablished its fiscal stability there
had not been a balanced budget for 15
years before me and the state
legislature gave me four years within
which to balance the budget or we go
into bankruptcy which was not an option
for me
and I balanced it in the third year a
year ahead of time the second thing I
did was I gave people back this spirit
the third thing I did was I took
politics out of the selection of judges
appointed by the mayor I appointed a
hundred and forty criminal and Family
Court judges and put it created a system
that was incredible and Rudy Giuliani
destroyed the system and brought
politics back in and the fourth thing it
is I was responsible when the federal
government the state government no
longer provided affordable housing
construction monies we built 250,000
housing units at affordable rates
I'd like you to rate your successors
well let's take him David Dinkins not a
good mayor nice man but should and will
always remembered for Crown Heights and
the fact that he believed that you let
people as he put it vent their rage not
when they're beating up other people and
killing at least
- Rudy Guiliani was a very good mayor
but he was not a very good person he was
mean-spirited and the best illustration
I can give you of that is that blacks
and Hispanics felt he was a racist and
they would complain to me he's a racist
I said absolutely not Rudy is not a
racist he is mean to everybody Mike
Bloomberg super era and the one thing
that he has done that nobody else was
able to do what do you mean was to bring
racial harmony to this town
there is no racial unrest in this town
none yeah occasionally an incident me
when he saw I all Sharpton in the first
days of his administration coming down
the steps he walked over to him and
shook his hand that was the right thing
to do who need whatever through that I'm
a friend of Al Sharpton so I certainly
would do that and I've criticized them
and I've said terrible things about him
but what he said always to the press is
but he never stopped talking to me
meaning me there's one thing that
Sharpton really really hates about you
though you upstaged him at his own
birthday party well he's right it was in
the church they said we're behind the
altar and I come out and and I get up
and I say to this crowd moving from left
to right
do you miss me and they roared with
pleasure and I enjoyed it
how do you want to be remembered both as
the mayor of New York and as I want to
be remembered as being a proud Jew who
loved the people of the city of New York
and did his best to make their lives
better
